Preliminaries: Linear Motion

Velocity and Acceleration

v(t)=dsdtv(t)=\frac{ds}{dt} v(t)=dtds​

a(t)=dvdt=d2sdt2a(t)=\frac{dv}{dt}=\frac{d^2s}{dt^2} a(t)=dtdv​=dt2d2s​

Infinitisimal Relations

∫v0vdv=∫0tadt\int_{v_0}^{v}dv=\int_{0}^{t}adt ∫v0​v​dv=∫0t​adt

dt=dsv(t)=dva(t)dt = \frac{ds}{v(t)}=\frac{dv}{a(t)} dt=v(t)ds​=a(t)dv​

a(t)ds=v(t)dv⇔a(s)ds=vdva(t) ds = v(t) dv \Leftrightarrow a(s)ds=vdv a(t)ds=v(t)dv⇔a(s)ds=vdv

∫v0vvdv=∫s0sads\int_{v_0}^{v}vdv=\int_{s_0}^{s}ads ∫v0​v​vdv=∫s0​s​ads

a(t)=v(t)(dvds)a(t)=v(t)\Big(\frac{dv}{ds}\Big) a(t)=v(t)(dsdv​)

Curvilinear Motion

Mathematical Background

All infinitismal segment of a curve can be thought of as a part of a circle. The distance between the center of the circle and the segment could be determined through the following procedure.

∥r⃗∥=∥dr⃗∥dθ=dsdθ\|\vec r\|=\frac{\|d\vec r\|}{d\theta}=\frac {ds}{d\theta} ∥r∥=dθ∥dr∥​=dθds​

General Velocity

v⃗=dr⃗dt\vec v=\frac{d \vec{r}}{d t} v=dtdr​

Magnitude wise, let Δs=∥Δr⃗∥\Delta s = \|\Delta\vec r\|Δs=∥Δr∥:

∥v⃗∥=dsdt\|\vec v\|=\frac {ds}{dt} ∥v∥=dtds​

General Acceleration

a⃗=dv⃗dt=d2r⃗dt2\vec a = \frac{d\vec v}{dt}=\frac{d^2\vec r}{dt^2} a=dtdv​=dt2d2r​

Rectangular Coordinate

r⃗=[xyz]\vec{r} = \begin{bmatrix}x\\y\\z\end{bmatrix} r=⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​

v⃗=dr⃗dt=x˙i^+y˙j^+z˙k^a⃗=dv⃗dt=x¨i^+y¨j^+z¨k^\vec v = \frac{d\vec r}{dt} = \dot x \hat i +\dot y\hat j +\dot z\hat k\\ \vec a = \frac{d\vec v}{dt} = \ddot x \hat i + \ddot y \hat j + \ddot z \hat k v=dtdr​=x˙i^+y˙​j^​+z˙k^a=dtdv​=x¨i^+y¨​j^​+z¨k^

Projectile

Characteristics:

  • horizontal component of the velocity always remains constant during the motion

Normal and Tangential Components

Center and Radius of Curvature

The Center of Curvature is denoted O′O'O′.

The Radius of Curvature is denoted ρ\rhoρ.

Let y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x),

ρ=[1+(y′)2]3/2∣y′′∣\rho = \frac{[1+(y')^2]^{3/2}}{|y''|} ρ=∣y′′∣[1+(y′)2]3/2​

Curvilinear Velocity has two components: tangential components with unit vector direction μt\mu_tμt​; normal components with unit vector direction μn\mu_nμn​.

Properties of μt\mu_tμt​ and μn\mu_nμn​:

∵∥ut⃗∥=∥un⃗∥=1∴∥dut⃗∥=∥ut⃗∥dθ=∥un⃗∥dθ\because\|\vec{u_t}\|=\|\vec{u_n}\|=1\\ \therefore \|d\vec{u_t}\|=\|\vec{u_t}\|d\theta=\|\vec{u_n}\|d\theta ∵∥ut​​∥=∥un​​∥=1∴∥dut​​∥=∥ut​​∥dθ=∥un​​∥dθ

∵dut⃗⊥ut⃗∧dut⃗∥un⃗∴dut⃗=dθ un⃗=dsρun⃗\because d\vec{u_t}\perp\vec{u_t}\wedge d\vec{u_t}\parallel \vec{u_n} \\ \therefore d\vec{u_t}=d\theta\ \vec{u_n} = \frac{ds}{\rho}\vec{u_n} ∵dut​​⊥ut​​∧dut​​∥un​​∴dut​​=dθ un​​=ρds​un​​

Velocities and Acceleration:

v⃗=∥v⃗∥μt⃗=s˙μt⃗\vec v = \|\vec v\|\vec{\mu_t} = \dot s \vec{\mu_t} v=∥v∥μt​​=s˙μt​​

a⃗=dv⃗dt=s¨μt⃗+s˙dut⃗dt=s¨ut⃗+s˙2ρun⃗\vec a = \frac{d\vec v}{dt} = \ddot s \vec{\mu_t}+ \dot s \frac{d\vec{u_t}}{dt} = \ddot s\vec{u_t}+\frac{{\dot s}^2}{\rho}\vec{u_n} a=dtdv​=s¨μt​​+s˙dtdut​​​=s¨ut​​+ρs˙2​un​​

Acceleration Shortcuts:

a⃗=atut⃗+anun⃗\vec a = a_t \vec{u_t} + a_n \vec{u_n} a=at​ut​​+an​un​​

at=s¨     an=s˙2ρa_t=\ddot s\ \ \ \ \ a_n = \frac{\dot s^2}{\rho} at​=s¨     an​=ρs˙2​

Spatial Curvature:

There will be a unique tangent axis, and a unique plane that contains the infinitismal arc, and a unique center of curvature O′O'O′.

The principal normal lines on the unique plane that contains the infinitismal arc and is perpendicular tothe tangent axis.

Polar Coordinate

Radial Coordinate denoted rrr extends outward from the fixed original OOO to the particle.

Tranverse Coordinate denoted θ\thetaθ is the angle between a fixed reference line and the rrr axis.

Radial Component of velocity is denoted vrv_rvr​

Transverse Component of velocity is denoted vθv_\thetavθ​

Position of a particle is defined by:

r⃗=∥r⃗∥ur⃗\vec r = \|\vec r\| \vec{u_r} r=∥r∥ur​​

Velocity is simply v⃗=dr⃗/dt=r˙u⃗r+rdu⃗r/dt=r˙ur⃗+rθ˙uθ⃗\vec v = d{\vec r}/dt = \dot r \vec u_r+rd\vec u_r/dt = \dot r \vec{u_r}+r\dot \theta\vec{u_\theta}v=dr/dt=r˙ur​+rdur​/dt=r˙ur​​+rθ˙uθ​​

Let u⃗r\vec u_rur​ be the unit vector with the direction from origin OOO to the particle. Let u⃗θ⊥u⃗r\vec u_\theta \perp \vec u_ruθ​⊥ur​ represent the unit vector with angular motion's direction.

∵∥du⃗r∥=dθ∥u⃗r∥∧dur⃗∥u⃗θ\because \|d\vec u_r\|=d\theta \|\vec u_r\| \wedge d\vec{u_r}\parallel \vec u_\theta ∵∥dur​∥=dθ∥ur​∥∧dur​​∥uθ​

∴dur⃗=dθuθ⃗\therefore d\vec{u_r} = d\theta \vec{u_\theta} ∴dur​​=dθuθ​​

Acceleration in polar coordinate is messy, just expand a⃗=dv⃗/dt\vec a = d\vec v / dta=dv/dt using product rule and you should get 5 terms.

∵∥du⃗θ∥=dθ∥u⃗θ∥\because \|d\vec u_\theta\|=d\theta \|\vec u_\theta\| ∵∥duθ​∥=dθ∥uθ​∥

∴duθ⃗=−dθur⃗\therefore d\vec{u_\theta} = -d\theta \vec{u_r} ∴duθ​​=−dθur​​

The negative sign is due to the opposite directions of ur⃗\vec{u_r}ur​​ and duθ⃗d\vec{u_\theta}duθ​​.

Velocity Shortcut:

v⃗=vrur⃗+vθuθ⃗\vec v = v_r\vec{u_r} + v_\theta \vec{u_\theta} v=vr​ur​​+vθ​uθ​​

vr=r˙     vθ=rθ˙v_r = \dot r\ \ \ \ \ v_\theta = r\dot \theta vr​=r˙     vθ​=rθ˙

Acceleration Shortcut:

a⃗=arur⃗+aθuθ⃗\vec a = a_r\vec{u_r} + a_\theta \vec {u_\theta} a=ar​ur​​+aθ​uθ​​

ar=r¨−rθ˙2     aθ=rθ¨+2r˙θ˙a_r =\ddot r - r\dot \theta^2\ \ \ \ \ a_\theta = r\ddot \theta + 2\dot r \dot \theta ar​=r¨−rθ˙2     aθ​=rθ¨+2r˙θ˙

Polar Coordinate and Spatial Curvature

Distance Shortcut: r⃗=rur⃗+zuz⃗\vec r = r\vec{u_r}+z\vec{u_z}r=rur​​+zuz​​

Velocity Shortcut: v⃗=vru^r+vθu^θ+vzu^z\vec v = v_r\hat u_r + v_\theta \hat u_\theta + v_z\hat u_zv=vr​u^r​+vθ​u^θ​+vz​u^z​

Motion Analysis

Labelling Conventions

  • Label relevant components of a system (e.g. pulley wheels) as A, B, C ...
  • Label relevant distance variables sA,sB,sCs_A, s_B, s_CsA​,sB​,sC​.
  • Label relevant constant length l1,la,lABl_1, l_a, l_{AB}l1​,la​,lAB​.
  • Label relevant velocity variable vA,vB,vCv_A, v_B, v_CvA​,vB​,vC​.
  • Label relevant acceleration variable aA,aB,aCa_A, a_B, a_CaA​,aB​,aC​.

Organizing Motion Equations

Organize all equations by 3 categories:

  • Position Equations
  • Velocity Equations
  • Acceleration Equations

Relative Motion

Translating Frames of Reference

Absolute Position: relative to fixed reference frame.

Inertial (Fixed) Reference Frame: non-accelerating, non-rotating and assumed as non-moving.

Trasnlating (Body-Fixed) Reference Frame: fixed to the body of moving particle.

Relative Position Vector to BBB from O′O'O′ is denoted R⃗B/O′\vec R_{B/O'}RB/O′​

Let OOO denote the origin of the fixed reference frame, O′O'O′ denote the translating frame of reference, BBB denote the target particle.

r⃗B=r⃗O′=r⃗B/O′\vec r_B = \vec r_{O'} = \vec r_{B/O'} rB​=rO′​=rB/O′​

v⃗B=v⃗O′+v⃗B/O′\vec v_B = \vec v_{O'} + \vec v_{B/O'} vB​=vO′​+vB/O′​

a⃗B=a⃗O′+a⃗B/O′\vec a_B = \vec a_{O'} + \vec a_{B/O'} aB​=aO′​+aB/O′​

Force and Acceleration

Introductory Formulas

Newton's Second Law of Motion:

F⃗=ma⃗\vec F = m\vec a F=ma

The general equation of motion is:

∑F⃗=ma⃗\sum \vec{F} = m \vec{a} ∑F=ma

Newton's Law of Gravitational Attraction:

F=Gm1m2r2F = G\frac{m_1m_2}{r^2} F=Gr2m1​m2​​

Weight (force):

W=mgW = mg W=mg

Inertial Reference Frame

When measuring acceleration, we measure it with respect to a reference frame that is either fixed or translates with a constant velocity. This reference frame is called an Inertial Reference Frame AKA Newtonian Refeerence Frame.

Impulse and Momentum

∑F⃗=ma⃗=mdv⃗dt\sum \vec{F} = m\vec{a} = m\frac{d\vec{v}}{dt} ∑F=ma=mdtdv​

∑∫t1t2F⃗dt=m∫v1v2dv⃗\sum\int_{t_1}^{t_2}\vec{F}dt = m\int_{v_1}^{v_2}d\vec{v} ∑∫t1​t2​​Fdt=m∫v1​v2​​dv

∑∫t1t2F⃗dt=mv⃗2−mv⃗1\sum\int_{t_1}^{t_2}\vec{F}dt=m\vec{v}_2-m\vec{v}_1 ∑∫t1​t2​​Fdt=mv2​−mv1​

Linear Moment (L) is a vector L⃗=mv⃗\vec L = m\vec vL=mv.

Linear Impulse (I) is a vector I⃗=∫F⃗dt\vec I=\int\vec F dtI=∫Fdt.

Overall,

I⃗1−2=L⃗2−L⃗1\vec I_{1-2}=\vec L_2-\vec L_1 I1−2​=L2​−L1​

mv⃗1+∑∫t1t2F⃗dt=mv⃗2 ⟹{m(vx)1+∑∫t1t2Fxdt=m(vx)2m(vy)1+∑∫t1t2Fydt=m(vy)2m(vz)1+∑∫t1t2Fzdt=m(vz)2m\vec v_1 + \sum \int_{t_1}^{t_2}\vec F dt=m\vec v_2 \ \Longrightarrow \begin{cases} m(v_x)_1 + \sum\int_{t_1}^{t_2}F_x dt = m(v_x)_2\\ m(v_y)_1 + \sum\int_{t_1}^{t_2}F_y dt = m(v_y)_2\\ m(v_z)_1 + \sum\int_{t_1}^{t_2}F_z dt = m(v_z)_2 \end{cases} mv1​+∑∫t1​t2​​Fdt=mv2​ ⟹⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​m(vx​)1​+∑∫t1​t2​​Fx​dt=m(vx​)2​m(vy​)1​+∑∫t1​t2​​Fy​dt=m(vy​)2​m(vz​)1​+∑∫t1​t2​​Fz​dt=m(vz​)2​​

Conservation of Linear Momentum

When the sum of external impulses acting on a system is zero, ∑mi(vi)1=∑mi(vi)2\sum m_i(v_i)_1=\sum m_i(v_i)_2∑mi​(vi​)1​=∑mi​(vi​)2​.

Let velocity of the mass center v⃗G=∑miv⃗i\vec v_G=\sum m_i\vec v_ivG​=∑mi​vi​, the _conservation of linear momentum indicates that (v⃗G)1=(v⃗G)2(\vec v_G)_1=(\vec v_G)_2(vG​)1​=(vG​)2​.

Internal impulses for the system alway7s cancel out. If period of time is very short, some external impulses may be considered zero. The forces causing negligible impulses are called non-impulsive forces.

Impact

Impact occurs when two bodies collide with each other during a very short period of time, causing relatively large (impulsive) forces to be exerted between the bodies.

Central Impact

Central impact occurs when the direction of motion of the mass centers of the two colliding particles is along a line of impact passing through the mass centers of the particles. The line of impact is perpendicular to the plane of contact.

During the collision the particles must be thought of as deformable. The particles will undergo a period of deformation such that they exert an equal but opposite deformation impulse ∫P⃗dt\int \vec P dt∫Pdt on each other.
Afterward, a period of restitution occurs, and the particles will either return to their original shape, or remain permanently deformed. The equal but opposite restitution impulse ∫R⃗dt\int\vec R dt∫Rdt pushes the particles apart from one another.
The deformation impulse will always be greater than the restitution impulse, i.e. ∫Pdt>∫Rdt\int P dt > \int R dt∫Pdt>∫Rdt

Let vvv denote the speed of the two particles during the collision. That is vvv is the velocity of both objects after the deformation impulse and before the restitution impulse.

mA(vA)1+mB(vB)1=mA(vA)2+mB(vB)2m_A(v_A)_1+m_B(v_B)_1=m_A(v_A)_2+m_B(v_B)_2 mA​(vA​)1​+mB​(vB​)1​=mA​(vA​)2​+mB​(vB​)2​

mA(vA)1−∫Pdt=mAvm_A(v_A)_1-\int Pdt = m_A v mA​(vA​)1​−∫Pdt=mA​v

mAv−∫Rdt=mA(vA)2m_A v - \int R dt = m_A(v_A)_2 mA​v−∫Rdt=mA​(vA​)2​

Coefficient of Restitution

Coefficient of Restitution eee is the ratio of restitution impulse to the deformation impulse.

e=∫Rdt∫Pdt=v−(vA)2(vA)1−v=(vB)2−vv−(vB)1e=\frac{\int R dt}{\int P dt} =\frac{v-(v_A)_2}{(v_A)_1 - v} =\frac{(v_B)_2-v}{v-(v_B)_1}e=∫Pdt∫Rdt​=(vA​)1​−vv−(vA​)2​​=v−(vB​)1​(vB​)2​−v​

Eliminating the unknown vvv, we get

e=(vB)2−(vA)2(vA)1−(vB)1e=\frac{(v_B)_2-(v_A)_2}{(v_A)_1-(v_B)_1} e=(vA​)1​−(vB​)1​(vB​)2​−(vA​)2​​

Coefficient of Restitution is essentially the ratio of the relative velocity of the particles just after impact to the relative velocity just before impact.

Elastic Impact occurs when e=1e=1e=1, Plastic Impact occurs when e=0e=0e=0.

If the collision is not perfectly elastic, the principle of work and energy cannot be used for the analysis of impact problems. The energy loss ∑U1−2=∑T2−∑T1\sum U_{1-2}=\sum T_2 - \sum T_1∑U1−2​=∑T2​−∑T1​ occurs because some of the initial kinetic energy of the particle is transformed into thermal energy. In spite of this, the momentum is always conserved.

Oblique Impact

First, define the x-y axes. The x-axis is along the line of impact (may be inclined, have to rotate your view), and the y-axis is in the plane of contact perpendicular to the x-axis.

Conservation of Momentum: momentum in both x,yx,yx,y directions are conserved.

{∑m(vx)1=∑m(vx)2∑m(vy)1=∑m(vy)2\begin{cases} \sum m(v_x)_1=\sum m(v_x)_2\\ \sum m(v_y)_1 = \sum m(v_y)_2 \end{cases} {∑m(vx​)1​=∑m(vx​)2​∑m(vy​)1​=∑m(vy​)2​​

Coefficient of Restitution: use coefficient of restitution for the x-direction (line of impact) through the formula of eee.

Angular Momentum

The angular momentum of a particle about point OOO is defined as the "moment" of the particle’s linear momentum about OOO. Since this concept is analogous to finding the moment of a force about a point, the angular momentum, HOH_OHO​, is sometimes referred to as the moment of momentum.

HO=r⃗×mv⃗H_O = \vec r\times m\vec v HO​=r×mv

HO=∣i^j^k^rxryrzmvxmvymvz∣H_O = \begin{vmatrix} \hat i & \hat j & \hat k \\ r_x & r_y & r_z \\ mv_x & mv_y & mv_z \end{vmatrix} HO​=∣∣∣∣∣∣​i^rx​mvx​​j^​ry​mvy​​k^rz​mvz​​∣∣∣∣∣∣​

where r⃗\vec rr is the position vector drawn from point OOO tot he particle, mv⃗m\vec vmv is the line of action of the linear momentum.

HOH_OHO​ is perpendicular to the plane containing r⃗,mv⃗\vec r, m\vec vr,mv.

Relating Moment of Force and Angular Momentum

{∑F=mv˙∑MO=r⃗×F⃗=r⃗×mv˙\begin{cases} \sum F = m\dot \bold{v}\\ \sum M_O=\vec r \times \vec F = \vec r \times m \dot \bold{v} \end{cases} {∑F=mv˙∑MO​=r×F=r×mv˙​

H˙O=ddt(r⃗×mv⃗)=r˙×mv⃗+r⃗×mv˙\dot \bold{H}_O=\frac{d}{dt}(\vec r\times m\vec v)=\cancel{\dot \bold{r}\times m\vec v}+\vec r \times m \dot \bold v H˙O​=dtd​(r×mv)=r˙×mv​+r×mv˙

As a result,

{∑MO=H˙O∑F=L˙\begin{cases} \sum \bold M_O = \dot \bold H_O\\ \sum \bold F = \dot \bold L \end{cases} {∑MO​=H˙O​∑F=L˙​

Where L⃗=mv⃗\vec L = m\vec vL=mv, the resultant moment about point OOO is equal to the time rate of change of the particle's angular momentum; the resultant force acting on the particle is equal to the time rate of change of the particle's linear momentum.

For a system of particles, we denote external force as Fi\bold F_iFi​, and a resultant internal force as fi\bold f_ifi​, we have

(ri×Fi)+(ri×fi)=(H˙i)O(\bold r_i \times \bold F_i) + (\bold r_i \times \bold f_i)=(\dot \bold H_i)_O (ri​×Fi​)+(ri​×fi​)=(H˙i​)O​

∑(ri×Fi)+∑(ri×fi)=∑(H˙i)O\sum(\bold r_i \times \bold F_i) + \cancel{\sum(\bold r_i \times \bold f_i)}=\sum(\dot \bold H_i)_O ∑(ri​×Fi​)+∑(ri​×fi​)​=∑(H˙i​)O​

Note that the second term is cancelled because internal forces occur in equal but opposite collinear pairs. Hence the moment of each pair about point OOO is zero. Again, ∑MO=H˙O\sum \bold M_O = \dot \bold H_O∑MO​=H˙O​ holds for system of particles.

Principle of Angular Impulse and Momentum

∑∫t1t2MOdt=(HO)2−(HO)1\sum \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \bold M_O dt = (\bold H_O)_2 - (\bold H_O)_1 ∑∫t1​t2​​MO​dt=(HO​)2​−(HO​)1​

(HO)1+∑∫t1t2MOdt=(HO)2(\bold H_O)_1 + \sum \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \bold M_O dt=(\bold H_O)_2 (HO​)1​+∑∫t1​t2​​MO​dt=(HO​)2​

Where angular impulse is ∫t1t2MOdt=∫t1t2(r×F)dt\int_{t_1}^{t_2} \bold M_O dt = \int_{t_1}^{t_2}(\bold r \times \bold F) dt∫t1​t2​​MO​dt=∫t1​t2​​(r×F)dt.

Conservation of Angular Momentum

When the angular impulses acting on a particle are all zero, the angular momentum is conserved.

∑(HO)1=∑(HO)2\sum(\bold H_O)_1=\sum(\bold H_O)_2 ∑(HO​)1​=∑(HO​)2​

Obviously, if no external impulse is applied to the particle, both linear and angular momentum will be conserved. In some cases, however, the particle’s angular momentum will be conserved and linear momentum may not. An example of this occurs when the particle is subjected only to a central force, e.g. the impulsive central force FFF is always directed toward point OOO. Hence, the angular impulse (moment) created by FFF about the zzz axis is always zero, and therefore angular momentum of the particle is conserved about this axis.

Planar Kinematics

Planar motion is defined as a body that moves along a 2D plane. There are 3 types of motions:

  • Translation
    • Rectilinear Translation: moves along a straight path
    • Curvilinear Translation: moves along a curved line.
  • Rotation rotation about a fixed axis.
  • General Plane Motion: a combination of translation and rotation.

Translation and Rotation of Rigid Body

For 2 points on the body A,BA, BA,B, we have

{rB=rA+rB/AvB=vAaB=aA\begin{cases} \bold r_B = \bold r_A+\bold r_{B/A}\\ \bold v_B = \bold v_A\\ \bold a_B = \bold a_A \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​rB​=rA​+rB/A​vB​=vA​aB​=aA​​

[↺+] ω=dθdt[\circlearrowleft^+]\ \omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt} [↺+] ω=dtdθ​

[↺+] α=dωdt=d2θdt2[\circlearrowleft^+]\ \alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}=\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} [↺+] α=dtdω​=dt2d2θ​

Where dθd\bold\thetadθ is the differential of angular displacement. ω\bold \omegaω is angular velocigy, α\bold \alphaα is the angular acceleration.

The key to relate α,θ,andω\alpha, \theta, and \omegaα,θ,andω is through the familiar formula:

αdθ=ωdω\alpha d\theta = \omega d\omega αdθ=ωdω

Relating Angular Attributes to Linear

{v=ωrv=ω⃗×r\begin{cases} v=\omega r\\ \bold v = \vec\omega \times \bold r \end{cases} {v=ωrv=ω×r​

{at=αran=ω2r⟹a=at+an=α⃗×r−ω2r\begin{cases} a_t=\alpha r\\ a_n = \omega^2 r \end{cases} \Longrightarrow \bold a = \bold a_t + \bold a_n = \vec\bold{\alpha} \times \bold r - \omega^2 \bold r {at​=αran​=ω2r​⟹a=at​+an​=α×r−ω2r

Additionally (just for fun), we could derive the acceleration of point PPP by taking the time derivative of velocity:

a=dvdt=dωdt×rP+ω×drPdt ⇐{α⃗=dω/dtdrP/dt=v=ω×rP\bold a = \frac{d\bold v}{dt}=\frac{d\bold\omega}{dt}\times \bold r_P + \bold \omega\times \frac{d\bold r_P}{dt} \ \Leftarrow \begin{cases} \vec \alpha = d\bold \omega / dt\\ d\bold r_P/dt = \bold v = \bold \omega \times \bold r_P \end{cases} a=dtdv​=dtdω​×rP​+ω×dtdrP​​ ⇐{α=dω/dtdrP​/dt=v=ω×rP​​

a=α×rP+ω×(ω×rP)\bold a = \bold \alpha \times \bold r_P + \bold \omega \times(\bold \omega \times \bold r_P) a=α×rP​+ω×(ω×rP​)

Note that ω×(ω×rP)=−ω2r\bold \omega \times (\bold \omega \times \bold r_P) = -\omega^2 \bold rω×(ω×rP​)=−ω2r, direction wise.

Absolute Motion Analysis

A general motion can be completely specified by knowing both the angular rotation of a line fixed in the body and the motion of a point on the body.

Absolute Motion Analysis relates the position of a point on a rigid body undergoing rectilinear motion (with the rectilinear distance sss) to the angular position θ\thetaθ of a line contained in the body.

Assume point PPP undergoes the rectilinear motion.

  • Position Coordinate Equation:
    • Locate point PPP on the body using a position coordinate sss (which is measured from a fixed origin and is directed along the stright-line path of motion of point PPP)
    • Measure from a fixed reference line the angular position θ\thetaθ of a line in the body.
    • Relate θ\thetaθ and sss, let s=f(θ)s=f(\theta)s=f(θ)

{s=f(θ)v=(f(θ))′=g(ω)a=(g(ω))′=h(α)\begin{cases} s=f(\theta)\\ v=\big(f(\theta)\big)'=g(\omega)\\ a=\big(g(\omega)\big)'=h(\alpha) \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​s=f(θ)v=(f(θ))′=g(ω)a=(g(ω))′=h(α)​

Relative Motion Analysis

Super intuitive.

{rB=rA+rB/AvB=vA+vB/AaB=aA+(aB/A)t+(aB/A)n\begin{cases} \bold r_B = \bold r_A + \bold r_{B/A}\\ \bold v_B = \bold v_A + \bold v_{B/A}\\ \bold a_B = \bold a_A + (\bold a_{B/A})_t+(\bold a_{B/A})_n \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​rB​=rA​+rB/A​vB​=vA​+vB/A​aB​=aA​+(aB/A​)t​+(aB/A​)n​​

When vB/Av_{B/A}vB/A​ is pure rotation, vB/A=ω⃗×rB/Av_{B/A}=\vec \omega \times \bold r_{B/A}vB/A​=ω×rB/A​

When aB/Aa_{B/A}aB/A​ is pure rotation, (aB/A)t=α⃗×rB/A, (aB/A)n=−ω2rB/A(\bold a_{B/A})_t=\vec\alpha\times\bold r_{B/A},\ (\bold a_{B/A})_n=-\omega^2 \bold r_{B/A}(aB/A​)t​=α×rB/A​, (aB/A​)n​=−ω2rB/A​.

Necessary components include:

  • Kinematic Diagram
  • Velocity Equation
  • Acceleration Equation

Instantaneous Center of Zero Velocity

Instantaneous Center (IC) of Zero Velocity is a point on or off the body that has zero velocity at a specific instant in time.

Recall the relative velocity equation for general motion vB=vA+ω⃗×rB/A\bold v_B = \bold v_A + \vec\omega\times\bold r_{B/A}vB​=vA​+ω×rB/A​. Choosing the instantaneous center of zero velocity (IC), we get rid of the translation vA\bold v_AvA​ term and renders the equation

vB=ω⃗×rB/IC\bold v_B = \vec\omega\times\bold r_{B/IC} vB​=ω×rB/IC​

If IC is determined, we can easily determine one of vB,ω,rB/ICv_B, \omega, r_{B/IC}vB​,ω,rB/IC​ given the other two.

To locate IC: we can use the fact that the velocity of a point on the body is always perpendicular to the relative-position vector directed from IC to the point.

  • Known velocity of one point vA\bold v_AvA​ and angular velocity. (ez)
  • Known velocities (non-parallel) of 2 points vA,vB\bold v_A, \bold v_BvA​,vB​. (ez)
  • Known velocity (parallel) of 2 points. Use magnitude and similar triangle to solve.

Centrode: the locus of points which define the location of IC during the body's motion. Each point on the centrode acts as the IC for the body only for an instant.

Although the IC may be conveniently used to determine the velocity of any point in a body, it generally does not have zero acceleration and therefore should not be used for finding accelerations of points in a body.

Relative-Motion Analysis using Rotating Axes

Relative Motion Analysis using a translating coordinate system is useful for deteremining the motion of points located on several pin-connected bodies. In some problems, however, rigid bodies are constructed such that sliding will occur at the connections.

As shown in the diagram, we use XYZXYZXYZ to denote the fixed coordinate system (origin is a fixed point) with unit vector I^,J^,K^\hat I, \hat J, \hat KI^,J^,K^. We use xyzxyzxyz to denote the rotating coordinate system (origin is base point A) with unit vectors i^,j^,k^\hat i, \hat j, \hat ki^,j^​,k^.

  • The position of B in xyzxyzxyz is r⃗B/A=xBi^+yBj^\vec{r}_{B/A}=x_B\hat{i}+y_B\hat{j}rB/A​=xB​i^+yB​j^​.
  • The positions of A and B in XYZXYZXYZ are r⃗A,r⃗B\vec{r}_A, \vec{r}_BrA​,rB​.

The relationship of the 3 position vectors is:

r⃗B=r⃗A+r⃗B/A\vec{r}_B=\vec{r}_A+\vec{r}_{B/A} rB​=rA​+rB/A​

i^,j^,k^\hat{i},\hat{j},\hat{k}i^,j^​,k^ are standard basis vector computed using fixed coordinate system XYZXYZXYZ. In other words, they are not the standard e^x,e^y,e^z\hat{e}_x,\hat{e}_y, \hat{e}_ze^x​,e^y​,e^z​.

The angular velocity and acceleration of the rotating axes is denoted Ω\OmegaΩ.

Rotating Axes Velocity Analysis

vB=vA+drB/Adt\bold v_B=\bold v_A+\frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt} vB​=vA​+dtdrB/A​​

where

drB/Adt=ddt(xBi+yBj)=(dxBdti+dyBdtj)+(xBdidt+yBdjdt)\begin{aligned} \frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt} &=\frac{d}{dt}(x_B\bold i + y_B\bold j)\\ &=\left(\frac{dx_B}{dt}\bold i+\frac{dy_B}{dt}\bold j\right) +\left(x_B\frac{d\bold i}{dt}+y_B\frac{d\bold j}{dt}\right) \end{aligned} dtdrB/A​​​=dtd​(xB​i+yB​j)=(dtdxB​​i+dtdyB​​j)+(xB​dtdi​+yB​dtdj​)​

  • The 2 term in the first paratheses represent components of velocity from xyzxyzxyz observer's point o view.
  • In the second set of paratheses, the instantaneous time rate of change of the unit vector i,j\bold i, \bold ji,j is measured by the fixed XYZXYZXYZ observer.

Observe that

didt=dθdt(j)=Ωj=Ω×i\frac{d\bold i}{dt}=\frac{d\theta}{dt}(\bold j)=\Omega\bold j=\bold \Omega\times \bold i dtdi​=dtdθ​(j)=Ωj=Ω×i

djdt=dθdt(−i)=−Ωi=Ω×j\frac{d\bold j}{dt}=\frac{d\theta}{dt}(-\bold i)=-\Omega \bold i=\bold \Omega\times \bold j dtdj​=dtdθ​(−i)=−Ωi=Ω×j

Substituting these and we get,

drB/Adt=(vB/A)xyz+Ω×(xBi+yBj)=(vB/A)xyz+Ω×rB/A\begin{aligned} \frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt}&=(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}+\bold\Omega\times(x_B\bold i+y_B\bold j)\\ &=(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}+\bold \Omega\times \bold r_{B/A} \end{aligned} dtdrB/A​​​=(vB/A​)xyz​+Ω×(xB​i+yB​j)=(vB/A​)xyz​+Ω×rB/A​​

Shortcut:

vB=vA+Ω×rB/A+(vB/A)xyz\bold v_B=\bold v_A+\bold \Omega\times\bold r_{B/A}+(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz} vB​=vA​+Ω×rB/A​+(vB/A​)xyz​

where

  • vB=\bold v_B=vB​= velocity of BBB, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference
  • vA=\bold v_A=vA​= velocity of origin AAA of the xyzxyzxyz refernece, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference.
  • (vB/A)xyz=(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}=(vB/A​)xyz​= velocity of BBB with respect to AAA, as measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference
  • Ω=\bold \Omega=Ω= angular velocity of the $xyz4 reference, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference.
  • rB/A=\bold r_{B/A}=rB/A​= position of BBB with respect to AAA.

Rotating Axis Acceleration Analysis

dvBdt=dvAdt+dΩdt×rB/A+Ω×drB/Adt+d(vB/A)xyzdtaB=aA+Ω˙×rB/A+Ω×drB/Adt+d(vB/A)xyzdt\begin{aligned} \frac{d\bold v_B}{dt} &= \frac{d\bold v_A}{dt}+\frac{d\bold \Omega}{dt}\times\bold r_{B/A}+\bold\Omega\times \frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt}+\frac{d(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}}{dt}\\ \bold a_B &= \bold a_A+\dot\bold\Omega\times\bold r_{B/A}+\bold\Omega\times \frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt}+\frac{d(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}}{dt} \end{aligned} dtdvB​​aB​​=dtdvA​​+dtdΩ​×rB/A​+Ω×dtdrB/A​​+dtd(vB/A​)xyz​​=aA​+Ω˙×rB/A​+Ω×dtdrB/A​​+dtd(vB/A​)xyz​​​

Where Ω˙\dot\bold\OmegaΩ˙ is the angular acceleration of the xyzxyzxyz coordinate system. We observe that

Ω×drB/Adt=Ω×(vB/A)xyz+Ω×(Ω×rB/A)\bold\Omega\times\frac{d\bold r_{B/A}}{dt}=\bold\Omega\times(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}+\bold\Omega\times(\bold\Omega\times\bold r_{B/A}) Ω×dtdrB/A​​=Ω×(vB/A​)xyz​+Ω×(Ω×rB/A​)

and ∵(vB/A)xyz=(vB/A)xi+(vB/A)yj\because (v_{B/A})_{xyz}=(v_{B/A})_x\bold i+(v_{B/A})_y\bold j∵(vB/A​)xyz​=(vB/A​)x​i+(vB/A​)y​j

∴d(vB/A)xyzdt=[d(vB/A)xdti+d(vB/A)ydtj]+[(vB/A)xdidt+(vB/A)ydjdt]=(aB/A)xyz+Ω×(vB/A)xyz\therefore \begin{aligned} \frac{d(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}}{dt} &=\left[\frac{d(v_{B/A})_x}{dt}\bold i+\frac{d(v_{B/A})_y}{dt}\bold j\right]+\left[(v_{B/A})_x\frac{d\bold i}{dt}+(v_{B/A})_y\frac{d\bold j}{dt}\right]\\ &=(\bold a_{B/A})_{xyz}+\bold\Omega\times(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz} \end{aligned} ∴dtd(vB/A​)xyz​​​=[dtd(vB/A​)x​​i+dtd(vB/A​)y​​j]+[(vB/A​)x​dtdi​+(vB/A​)y​dtdj​]=(aB/A​)xyz​+Ω×(vB/A​)xyz​​

Substituting these and we get the Shortcut:

aB=aA+Ω˙×rB/A+Ω×(Ω×rB/A)+2Ω×(vB/A)xyz+(aB/A)xyz\bold a_B=\bold a_A+\dot\bold\Omega\times\bold r_{B/A}+\bold \Omega\times(\bold\Omega\times\bold r_{B/A})+2\bold\Omega\times(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}+(\bold a_{B/A})_{xyz} aB​=aA​+Ω˙×rB/A​+Ω×(Ω×rB/A​)+2Ω×(vB/A​)xyz​+(aB/A​)xyz​

where

  • aB=\bold a_B=aB​= acceleration of BBB, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference
  • aA=\bold a_A=aA​= acceleration of origin AAA of the xyzxyzxyz reference, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference
  • (aB/A)xyz,(vB/A)xyz=(\bold a_{B/A})_{xyz},(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}=(aB/A​)xyz​,(vB/A​)xyz​= acceleration and velocity of BBB with respect to AAA, as measured by an observer attached to the rotating xyzxyzxyz reference
  • Ω˙,Ω=\dot\bold\Omega,\bold\Omega =Ω˙,Ω= angular acceleration and angular velocity of the xyzxyzxyz reference, measured from the XYZXYZXYZ reference.
  • rB/A=\bold r_{B/A}=rB/A​= position of BBB with respect to AAA.

2Ω×(vB/A)xyz2\bold\Omega\times(\bold v_{B/A})_{xyz}2Ω×(vB/A​)xyz​ is called the Coriolis acceleration. This term represents the difference in the acceleration of BBB as measured from nonrotating and rotating xyzxyzxyz axes.

Important Examples:

Mass Moment of Inertia

Moment vector M\bold MM and angular acceleration α\bold \alphaα is related through the equation M=Iα⃗\bold M = I\vec\alphaM=Iα, where III is the mass moment of inertia.

Moment of Inertia is a measure of resistance of a body to angular acceleration, in the same way that mass is a measure of the body's resistance to acceleration. One could see the parallel:

{M=Iα⃗F=ma\begin{cases}\bold M=I\vec \alpha\\ \bold F=m\bold a\end{cases} {M=IαF=ma​

To compute the mass moment of inertia, we have the following cases:

{I=∫mr2 dm(general form)I=∫mr2(ρ dV)(equivalent to above)I=ρ∫mr2 dV(density is constant)\begin{cases} I=\int_m r^2\ dm & \textrm{(general form)}\\ I=\int_m r^2 (\rho\ dV) & \textrm{(equivalent to above)}\\ I=\rho \int_m r^2\ dV & \textrm{(density is constant)} \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​I=∫m​r2 dmI=∫m​r2(ρ dV)I=ρ∫m​r2 dV​(general form)(equivalent to above)(density is constant)​

Analysis Procedure: assumption is that we will only consider symmetric bodies having volumes which are generated by revolving a curve about an axis.

  • Shell Element: let height be zzz, radius r=yr=yr=y, and thickness dydydy is chosen for integration. The volume dV=(2πy)(z)dydV=(2\pi y)(z)dydV=(2πy)(z)dy.
  • Disk Element: let radius be yyy and thickness dzdzdz is chosen. We have infinitismal volume dV=(πy2)dzdV=(\pi y^2)dzdV=(πy2)dz. !!

Note that Disk Element's parts do not all lie at the same radial distance rrr from the zzz axis. As a result, we cannot use I=ρ∫mr2 dVI=\rho \int_m r^2\ dVI=ρ∫m​r2 dV directly. Instead, we must determine the moment of inertia of the infinitismal element about the zzz axis and then integrate the result.

Some quick examples.

Parallel Axis Theorem

If the moment of inertia of the body about an axis passing through the body's mass center is known, then the moment of inertia about any other parallel axis can be determined through parallel-axis theorem:

I=IG+md2I=I_G+md^2 I=IG​+md2

where

  • IG=I_G=IG​= moment of inertia about the z′z'z′ axis passing through the mass center GGG
  • m=m=m= mass of the body
  • d=d=d= perpendicular distance between the parallel zzz and z′z'z′ axes.

Composite Bodies' MMI is determined by algebraically adding together all mass moments of inertia about the same axis.

Some additional examples:

Radius of Gyration

Radius of Gyration kkk is a measure of the distribution of the body's mass about the axis at which the moment of inertia is defined:

I=mk2 or k=ImI=mk^2\textrm{ or }k=\sqrt{\frac{I}{m}} I=mk2 or k=mI​​

Note the similarity

{dI=r2dmI=k2m\begin{cases}dI=r^2dm\\I=k^2m\end{cases} {dI=r2dmI=k2m​

Rigid Body Translation and Rotation

Equations of Translational Motion

The sum of all the external forces acting on the body is equal to the body's mass times the acceleration of its mass center GGG.

∑F=maG\sum\bold{F}=m\bold{a}_G ∑F=maG​

{∑Fx=m(aG)x∑Fy=m(aG)y\begin{cases} \sum\bold{F}_x=m(\bold{a}_G)_x \sum\bold{F}_y=m(\bold{a}_G)_y \end{cases} {∑Fx​=m(aG​)x​∑Fy​=m(aG​)y​​

where aG\bold{a}_GaG​ denotes the acceleration of the mass center.

Equations of Rotational Motion

The rotational equation of motion states that the sum of the moments of all the external forces about hte body's mass center GGG is equal to the product of the moment of inertia of the body about an axis passing through GGG and the body's angular acceleration.

The moment about point PPP can be written as

∑(ri×Fi)+∑Mi=r‾×maG+IGα⃗\sum(\bold r_i\times \bold F_i)+\sum\bold M_i=\overline{\bold r}\times m\bold a_G+I_G\vec\alpha ∑(ri​×Fi​)+∑Mi​=r×maG​+IG​α

where r‾=x‾i+y‾j\overline{r}=\overline{x}\bold i+\overline{y}\bold jr=xi+y​j as shown in the diagram. x‾\overline{x}x is the x coordinate of the centroid relative to point PPP, and y‾\overline{y}y​ is the y coordinate of the centroid relative to point PPP.

The left side of the equation is the sum of the external forces and moments, denoted ∑MP\sum M_P∑MP​, the right side of the equation is the resultant acceleration, denoted ∑(Mk)P\sum(\mathcal M_k)_P∑(Mk​)P​. ∑(Mk)P\sum(\mathcal M_k)_P∑(Mk​)P​ is the kinetic moment about P (the overall resultant moment manifested through acceleration).

∑(Mk)P=r‾×maG+IGα\sum(\mathcal M_k)_P=\overline{\bold r}\times m\bold a_G+I_G\alpha ∑(Mk​)P​=r×maG​+IG​α

(see diagram below)

The equation of rotational motion is equivalent to this form:

∑MP=∑(Mk)P\sum M_P=\sum(\mathcal M_k)_P ∑MP​=∑(Mk​)P​

We also observe that if PPP coincide with GGG, x‾=y‾=0\overline{x}=\overline{y}=0x=y​=0, and therefore

∑MG=IGα\sum M_G=I_G\alpha ∑MG​=IG​α

Quick shortcut (summary):

{∑Fx=m(aG)x∑Fy=m(aG)y∑MG=IGα∑MP=∑(Mk)P\begin{cases} \sum F_x=m(a_G)_x\\ \sum F_y=m(a_G)_y\\ \sum M_G= I_G\alpha\\ \sum M_P=\sum{(\mathcal M_k)_P} \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​∑Fx​=m(aG​)x​∑Fy​=m(aG​)y​∑MG​=IG​α∑MP​=∑(Mk​)P​​

Types of Motion, Properties and Equations

Rectilinear Translation

When a body is subjected to rectilinear translation, all the particles of the body travel along parallel straightline paths.

We have

{∑Fx=m(aG)x∑Fy=m(aG)y∑MG=0\begin{cases} \sum F_x=m(a_G)_x\\ \sum F_y=m(a_G)_y\\ \sum M_G=0 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​∑Fx​=m(aG​)x​∑Fy​=m(aG​)y​∑MG​=0​

It is also possible to sum moments about other points on or off the body.

↺+∑MA=∑(Mk)A\circlearrowleft +\sum M_A=\sum(\mathcal M_k)_A ↺+∑MA​=∑(Mk​)A​

∑MA=(maG)d\sum M_A=(ma_G)d ∑MA​=(maG​)d

Curvilinear Translation

When a rigid body is subjected to curvilinear translation, all the particles of the body have the same accelerations as they travel along curved paths.

We have

{∑Fn=m(aG)n∑Ft=m(aG)t∑MG=0\begin{cases} \sum F_n=m(a_G)_n\\ \sum F_t=m(a_G)_t\\ \sum M_G = 0 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​∑Fn​=m(aG​)n​∑Ft​=m(aG​)t​∑MG​=0​

If the moments are summed about the arbitrary point B, then it is necessary to account for the moment ∑(Mk)B\sum(\mathcal M_k)_B∑(Mk​)B​ of the 2 components m(aG)n,m(aG)tm(\bold a_G)_n, m(\bold a_G)_tm(aG​)n​,m(aG​)t​ about this point.

Let h,eh,eh,e represent the perpendicular distances from BBB to the lines of action of the components. The required moment equation therefore becomes

↺+∑MB=∑(Mk)B\circlearrowleft+\sum M_B=\sum(\mathcal M_k)_B ↺+∑MB​=∑(Mk​)B​

∑MB=e[m(aG)t]−h[m(aG)n]\sum M_B=e[m(a_G)_t]-h[m(a_G)_n] ∑MB​=e[m(aG​)t​]−h[m(aG​)n​]

(See the diagram below)

Standard Analysis Procedure:

  • Free Body Diagram is a must, even on seemingly trivial components.
    • Establish xy/ntxy/ntxy/nt coordinate system.
  • Kinetic Diagram (Optional) if rotational equation ∑MP=∑(Mk)P\sum M_P=\sum(\mathcal M_k)_P∑MP​=∑(Mk​)P​ is involved, since it graphically accounts for the components m(aG)x,m(aG)y,m(aG)n,m(aG)tm(\bold a_G)_x, m(\bold a_G)_y, m(\bold a_G)_n, m(\bold a_G)_tm(aG​)x​,m(aG​)y​,m(aG​)n​,m(aG​)t​
  • Equations of Motion: apply the 3 equations of motion (summation of forces and moments)
  • Kinematic Equations: basic calculation of acceleration, velocity and distance.

If the body is in contact with a rough surface and slipping occurs, use the friction equation F=μkNF=\mu_k NF=μk​N (where FFF denotes friction!).

Some demonstrative examples:

Rotation About Fixed Axis

Consider a rigid body pinned at point O as shown in the figure below.

We know the following:

{(aG)n=ω2rG(aG)t=αrG\begin{cases} (a_G)_n=\omega^2 r_G\\ (a_G)_t=\alpha r_G \end{cases} {(aG​)n​=ω2rG​(aG​)t​=αrG​​

Draw the kinetic digram diagrams as shown in the figure (b) above, we obtain these:

{∑Fn=m(aG)n=mω2rG∑Ft=m(aG)t=mαrG∑MG=IGα\begin{cases} \sum F_n=m(a_G)_n=m\omega^2 r_G\\ \sum F_t=m(a_G)_t=m\alpha r_G\\ \sum M_G=I_G\alpha \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​∑Fn​=m(aG​)n​=mω2rG​∑Ft​=m(aG​)t​=mαrG​∑MG​=IG​α​

To obtain the moment equation of point OOO, we use the fact:

↺+∑MO=∑(Mk)O=rGm(aG)t+IGα=(IG+mrG2)α[IO=IG+md2]=IOα[Parallel Axis Theorem]\begin{aligned} \circlearrowleft+\sum M_O&=\sum(\mathcal M_k)_O\\ &=r_G m(a_G)_t+I_G\alpha\\ &=(I_G+mr_G^2)\alpha & [I_O=I_G+md^2]\\ &=I_O\alpha & \textrm{[Parallel Axis Theorem]} \end{aligned} ↺+∑MO​​=∑(Mk​)O​=rG​m(aG​)t​+IG​α=(IG​+mrG2​)α=IO​α​[IO​=IG​+md2][Parallel Axis Theorem]​

Therefore,

{∑MG=IGα∑MO=IOα\begin{cases} \sum M_G= I_G\alpha\\ \sum M_O = I_O \alpha \end{cases} {∑MG​=IG​α∑MO​=IO​α​

Standard Analysis Procedure:

  • Free Body Diagram: as always, establish n,tn,tn,t coordinate system.
  • Kinematic Diagram (optional)
  • Equation of Motion and Kinematics

The direction of aG\bold a_GaG​ must be consistent with the direction of α\alphaα (if you don't want to lose marks).

Some quick examples:

General Plane Motion

As with discussed before, there are only 4 formulas for this one:

{∑Fx=m(aG)x∑Fy=m(aG)y∑MG=IGα∑MP=∑(Mk)P where ∑(Mk)P=IGα+maG\begin{cases} \sum F_x=m(a_G)_x\\ \sum F_y=m(a_G)_y\\ \sum M_G=I_G\alpha\\ \sum M_P = \sum(\mathcal M_k)_P & \textrm{ where } \sum(\mathcal M_k)_P=I_G\bold\alpha+m\bold a_G \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​∑Fx​=m(aG​)x​∑Fy​=m(aG​)y​∑MG​=IG​α∑MP​=∑(Mk​)P​​ where ∑(Mk​)P​=IG​α+maG​​

Moment Equation About IC

There is a particular type of problem involves a uniform disk, or body of circular shape that rolls on a rough surface without slipping.

If we sum the moments about the instantaneous center of zero velocity, then ∑(Mk)IC\sum(\mathcal M_k)_{IC}∑(Mk​)IC​ becomes IICαI_{IC}\alphaIIC​α. Therefore

∑MIC=IICα\sum M_{IC}=I_{IC}\alpha ∑MIC​=IIC​α

This result compares with ∑MO=IOα\sum M_O=I_O\alpha∑MO​=IO​α, which is used for a body pinned at point OOO.

Some quick examples:

Case Study: Frictional Rolling Problems

Consider a disk with mass mmm, radius rrr, subjected to a known force PPP, with frictional force FFF.

We get the following equations of motion:

∑Fx=m(aG)x⇒P−F=maG∑Fy=m(aG)y⇒N−mg=0∑MG=IGα⇒F⋅r=IGα\begin{aligned} \sum F_x=m(a_G)_x &\Rightarrow P-F=m a_G\\ \sum F_y=m(a_G)_y &\Rightarrow N-mg=0\\ \sum M_G = I_G\alpha &\Rightarrow F\cdot r=I_G\alpha \end{aligned} ∑Fx​=m(aG​)x​∑Fy​=m(aG​)y​∑MG​=IG​α​⇒P−F=maG​⇒N−mg=0⇒F⋅r=IG​α​

There are 4 unknowns (F,N,α,aGF, N, \alpha, a_GF,N,α,aG​) and 3 equations. A 4th equation is required to solve all unknowns:

  • Case 1 - no slipping: aG=αra_G=\alpha raG​=αr is the 4th equation.
    • DO NOT use Ff=μsNF_f=\mu_s NFf​=μs​N.
    • After solving, one MUST verify that the assumption was correct (F≤μsN)(F\le\mu_s N)(F≤μs​N)
  • Case 2 - slipping: Ff=μkNF_f=\mu_k NFf​=μk​N is the 4th equation
    • aG≠αra_G\neq \alpha raG​̸​=αr
